titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. In Senate this forenoon The Insurance Company Bill was taken up, and the debate upon it continued, but not finished. The Committee of both houses on Mr Coffin’s motion for applying to Congress for permission to sell our Stocks in the funds of the United States, met and agreed to report it inexpedient. Mr: Coffin and myself contra— In the afternoon the Committee on Mr: Bidwell’s bill for a Reporter met— We continued to disagree upon our principles— Mr: Eli is on the Committee instead of Mr: Morton. I spent the remnant of the afternoon at my Office, and the Evening at home.

2. The Senate this day got through the bill for incorporating an Insurance Company, and several others. They took up the report of the Committee that it is inexpedient to apply to Congress for leave to sell our stocks, and rejected it— The Committee on the banks were to meet this Evening, at six o’clock: but upon going to the State house, we found the doors shut— Postponed the meeting therefore untill to-morrow— Dined at Mr: Bussey’s, with a Company of twenty Gentlemen. Spent the Evening at club, at Mr: Smith’s— Mrs: Adams went out to Roxbury and dined with Mrs: Dexter. She returned early in the evening.— Mr: Ames dined with us at Mr: Bussey’s— As we were leaving the house together I told him that I had heard that both his name and mine were upon the nomination list,
now in the house of Representatives, for the choice of a Senator in Congress— I asked him whether he would accept the Office, if chosen, and assured him, that if he would, my name should not stand in competition with his— That I would take care to have it removed; and should be highly gratified to contribute all in my power towards securing his election— He said he was entirely out of the question— That he could not go at any rate, and that if his name was upon the nomination list, it was altogether without his knowledge or consent— He said the federalists were driving on just like a militia, without concert or order, and that some measures ought to be taken to produce Union among them— That there would be two Senators to be chosen this Session, as Mr: Foster would certainly resign; and Mr: Mason declines a re-election— That there were two men to be provided for, and that measures should be pursued to prevent the excitement of ambition, and of course to produce the leaven of disappointment in a multitude of good men, who could have no reasonable pretensions, and whose feelings ought not to be tampered— I told him that concurring entirely with him in the sentiment, that something should be done to obtain united action and exertion, this was an occasion upon which I could do no more than say that I would cordially assist on my part in supporting or promoting the election of any one or two men other than myself, upon whom they would agree— Here this matter rested— The House of Representatives, last Saturday assigned to-morrow 12 o’clock, to make choice of the Senator for six years, instead of Mr: Mason whose time expires on the 4th: of March.— The Centinel and Palladium, published that the time assigned was next Saturday. Mr: Russell of Boston moved this day in the house to postpone the choice untill next Tuesday— Mr. Otis argued in favour of the postponement— The vote pass’d, but was afterwards re-considered, and the original time again assigned, for to-morrow 12 o’clock— This hurrying on is occasioned by a coalition of the Jacobin party (so called) with the Junto, who expect to carry Mr: Pickering for the six years, and then to start another candidate, if Mr: Foster should resign.

3. The business in Senate this forenoon was of little importance— No bills of general interest being before them— About 1. o’clock Mr: Otis came up from the house with a message— That the house had proceeded to the choice of a Senator in the Congress of the United States, in the room of Jonathan Mason, whose time of service expires on the fourth of March next— And that on the ballots being taken it appeared that John Quincy Adams had a majority of the whole number.— The Senate assigned next Tuesday 12 o’clock to act upon this choice, and a nomination list in the mean time to be put up— Mr: Pickman immediately put my name upon the nomination list, and the name of Timothy Pickering was immediately after inserted— I know not by whom.— In the afternoon the Committee upon the applications for Banks met at the Land-Office and sat untill almost eight o’clock. We had the petitions from Newbury-Port, Boston, Salem, North Hampton and New-Bedford before us and heard the petitioners. We finally agreed to give leave to bring in bills, to all excepting at Boston, which was deferred for another hearing to-morrow— We had a severe thunder shower this evening.— At home the latter part of it— And play’d Back-gammon with Mrs: Adams.

Before the choice made in the house of Representatives, Mr: Pickman told me that as there would certainly be two vacancies in the Senate of the United States, he wished that Mr: Pickering and myself
might be chosen to fill them— But one of the places being for the whole six years, and the other only a remnant he thought Mr: Pickering’s age, and the cruel persecutions of calumny which he had suffered gave him the right to the first choice— He thought him an honest and an able man, though of an unaccommodating and too assuming temper— His volunteering an answer to an Address from Princess Ann County, instead of laying the address before the President had always struck him as a very improper thing— He ask’d me whether the difference between Mr: Pickering and my father would have such influence on me, as to make me unwilling to sit in the same house with him.— I told him I had no personal resentment against Mr: Pickering whatever; and far from wishing to exclude him I would cordially give my vote for him, and for any other man upon whom the federalists would agree.— He then said that he had made up his mind, not to be active at all in the election; but to vote for the person whom the house should send up, provided he should think him a suitable person— And he added that he most sincerely wished Mr: Pickering had not suffered his name to be put up.
There were four trials in the house before the choice was made— The candidates and the numbers of votes at the several trials stood as follows.

The reason of the election’s taking such an extraordinary turn, I am told was this— A caucus of about twenty members was held last evening at Mr: Russell’s house. They could not agree together upon supporting either Mr: Pickering or me— Each being proposed and urged by several persons. At length it was agreed by way of compromise, that Mr: Pickering should have the first chance, of two trials. And if his election could not then be carried they would unite for me— This agreement was but very imperfectly complied with at the third trial— At the two first and the fourth it was executed as faithfully as such things ever can be— At the Caucus Mr: Lowell and Mr: Otis were warm partizans for Mr: Pickering— Of Lowell I could expect no less— Nor indeed of Otis— For he has of his own accord told me several times that as Mr: Mason would certainly decline a re-election, he the said Otis, meant to use all his endeavours to get me chosen in his stead— How could I possibly imagine then that Otis would propose or support any man but Pickering.

4. At 9 this morning, I attended the Committee on applications for new trials, in behalf of Mr. Boylston— They agreed upon an order of notice to Mr. Gill— The business transacted in the Senate was not very important.— After we adjourned Otis took me into one of the lobbies, to talk with me upon the subject of the application for a new bank in the town of Boston— He
said I had no conception of the interest and agitation which this affair had excited— That the application embraced a great multitude of the most respectable persons in this town, and almost the whole commercial interest— That it appeared to be an opinion among them, that it depended entirely upon me, and he had heard I had objections against the plan, which he wished to remove if possible— He understood the Committee had required the Subscription paper to ascertain the names of the persons concerned and the amount of their subscriptions— He made no hesitation to avow that he was interested in it— He had never concealed it, and never wished to conceal it; but at the same time he did not wish to have his name appear to be animadverted upon by every member of the legislature and by the public abroad.— That he would tell me exactly how the plan was formed— The establishment of a new bank in this town had been talk’d of these two or three years; but lately about twenty Gentlemen, met together, and projecting to unite all the great and respectable interests in the town, had chosen a Committee from among themselves to offer the subscription round to every gentleman of respectable character, and to apportion the amount which each person should be allowed to subscribe. That no individual subscriber was to take more than fifty shares, excepting the original projectors themselves— That the two Insurance-Offices were to have two thousand shares each; but were to give up five hundred shares a’piece, if such shares should be found necessary for any unforeseen demand— And that one thousand shares should be reserved, to be taken by the twenty original projectors, among themselves, for their extraordinary trouble and attention— The fact was that if the plan should be defeated, it would be solely owing to the liberality with which it was undertaken— If it should be defeated, the Jacobins would undertake and carry through a bank of their own, of which they had even matured a project— That had subsided only in consequence of the bank now proposed, for when Dr: Jarvis was applied to subscribe this application he refused, alledging that he had already signed another application— Finally his principal object in thus talking with me was to say that there could be no necessity for having a subscription paper containing the names of the parties interested bandied about in public— I told him I was sensible how deep how large and how powerful an interest was combined in the pursuit of this project— That so far from contending against such a respectable weight of influence, it would be my strongest wish to comply with and promote every thing they should desire, so far as might be consistent with my duty— That the Committee on which I sat were equally divided; two being for giving leave to bring in a bill without limitation, and two absolutely against it— That so far the question depended upon me.— But it had been rumoured abroad that in forming the capital of this Bank a certain number of shares was reserved, to be distributed among the members of the legislature; and this was a species of influence so dishonourable to the legislature itself, that I considered it indispensable to remove as far as could be the possibility of such a suspicion— That in consequence of this I had suggested, and the Committee had adopted the idea of calling for the subscription paper— But I presumed there would be no necessity for making it public.

At 1/2 past three in the afternoon the Committee met again; but Mr: Treadwell the chairman was not present— Mr: Higginson, Mr: Lyman, and Mr: Lloyd again came, and urged further arguments to recommend their plan, and to remove objections— They produced their subscription paper; but as the Committee
thought no reservation ought to remain unappropriated, they took back the paper to have it fill’d up— The Committee agreed to give them leave to bring in a bill— But with condition that some clause should be introduced to indemnify the Commonwealth for the loss it will sustain upon its Union Bank Shares. And that the specie for the vaults of the New-Bank, shall not be drawn from any Bank incorporated by the Commonwealth.

The Committee rose between 6 and 7.— I then pass’d an hour at my Office, where Mr: Gardner call’d— The remainder of the Evening, I attended the Society— Where Judge Davis and Dr: Jackson lectured. Young Dr: Warren was there.

5. Several bills pass’d in the Senate this morning— But no business of much debate is done on Saturday’s or Mondays— My mother and Mrs: Cranch came into town to attend the funeral of Miss Eunice Paine, from the house of her brother the Judge— I also attended, and afterwards went with my mother out to Quincy— I was unwell the whole day with a severe head ache.

6. The weather which had been alternately cold to excess, and unusually warm every other day for this month past, this day turn’d to a steady rain which continued the whole day. Brought the frost quite out of the ground. Attended Mr: Whitney— Assembly very thin, and no women— The remainder of the day I spent chiefly in writing.

7. Return’d to Boston this morning with John in the Chaise— The travelling very bad— Attended in the Senate, untill 2 o’clock.— Dr: Aspinwall, who has scarcely attended in his place at all, this session or the last, made his appearance this day.— At 1/2 past three in the afternoon, the Committee on Simpson’s petition met, and continued the investigation of his claim, but without coming to any positive conclusion— At my Office in the beginning of the Evening, Mr: James Lloyd called and conversed with me on the subject of the proposed bank— He was very desirous that I should give it not only my vote, but my support. I stated my objections, and my intentions, particularly of proposing a general subscription, to which he strongly objected— I find it a subject of no small difficulty how to conduct upon this occasion— Latter part of the evening at home. Charlotte Welsh pass’d the evening with the Ladies— Caroline, return’d from Mrs: Dexter’s this morning.

8. The Senate was occupied in discussing several bills and motions, untill 12 o’clock— The time assigned for the choice of a Senator in Congress for 6 years after the 4th: of March next— The number of votes was twenty-six (of course, I did not vote at-all)— There were nineteen votes for John Quincy Adams, and seven for Tompson J. Skinner— The federal side of the house therefore was unanimous to concur in the choice made by the house— Afterwards the choice of a person to preach the next election Sermon was made— There were two trials— At the first Dr: Morse had 12 votes, Reuben Puffer 7 and Paul Litchfield six— At the second Mr: Puffer had fourteen and was chosen— The Jacobins all voted for him to prevent the election of Dr: Morse.— A choice was next made of two persons to superintend the printing of an Edition of the private Statutes. Mr: P. Coffin, and John Davis were chosen— Lastly two agents were chosen as guardians of certain tribes of Indians—Jonathan Woodbury and EliLittle business else was done— In the afternoon I attended the Committee raised to consider and report upon the returns from the banks— Ball in the Evening at Mr: Otis’s—nearly a hundred persons there— Mrs: & Miss Dexter went with us— Miss Dexter came and pass’d the night with
Caroline; but Mrs: Dexter return’d home to Roxbury— I play’d cards and danced alternately. We came home between 12 and 1. in the morning.

9. The Senate had the subject of the several petitions for New-Banks before them— The petitioners from North Hampton and New-Bedford had leave granted them without a division— On the question for the Salem bill the votes were ten and ten, and they obtained leave by the casting vote of the President— In the afternoon I attended again the Committee on the returns of the Banks— We did not wholly accomplish our business— Mr: Gardner called on me at the Senate chamber; and went and pass’d part of the evening with me at my Office— Rest of the evening at Dr: Spooner’s, with the Club.— Recd: my credentials as Senator of the United States.

10. The principal business before the Senate was the reported address for the removal of the two Judges of the Sessions and Common Pleas, which was carried by yeas and nays 14 to 10— I wrote a dissent which I requested might be entered upon the Journals. The subject was postponed untill to-morrow— In the afternoon I attended at the Committee on the returns from the Banks. Evening at the Ball, where I danc’d and play’d whist untill about midnight.

11. The Committee on the Statements return’d from the banks made a report which was discussed, accepted and sent down to the house— The Committee appointed to confer with the Committee from the town of Boston, upon the subject of the old State-house, also made a report, which was debated, adopted, and a vote predicated upon it, to choose by ballot a Committee of three as Agents of the Legislature to treat with those of the town, and sell the right of the Commonwealth.— The Committee of rolls was again appointed; Mr: Pickman in the room of Mr: Dummer who is absent, and myself. Dined at Mr: Smith’s, in company with the Governor and a number of other gentlemen— My father was expected but did not come— In the afternoon at 5 I attended at the Committee of Rolls, and examined all the engrossed bills— Evening at the Society, where Judge Davis read a synopsis of Lavoisier—first part Chapter 13, 14, & 15— Home earlier than usual.

12. The Saturday business in the Senate is seldom very important, and indeed we have little else to do, but to make turnpikes, bridges and Banks; and incorporate towns, parishes, and religious Societies— My protest against the address was taken up, but not decided on, the subject being still before the House of Representatives— Dined at Mr: J. C. Jones’s; with the Governor, and a company of about fifteen gentlemen— At 5. return’d home, and went out to Quincy, with Louisa Smith and Charlotte Welsh.— Mr: Shaw went out with Mr: Black.

13. Rain’d and thaw’d the greatest part of the day— Heard Mr: Whitney.— Spent the remainder of the day and evening, chiefly in translating and writing— I am drawing towards a close with the Oration de Socrate Cive.

14. Return’d to Boston this morning, with Mr: Shaw— The roads extremely heavy.— Attended at the Senate—received a letter from General Knox, requesting the reasons of my dissent from the vote of the Senate on the address for removing the Judges— Sent him a copy of my reasons— Dined at Mr:
D. Sears’s in Company with the Governor and sixteen other Gentlemen— Evening at home, reading to the ladies the conclusion of Shakespear’s tempest, and part of His Two Gentlemen of Verona.

15. The question upon the petition for a new Bank in Boston, whether leave should be given to bring in a bill, was discussed and decided— The leave was given.— The House of Representatives have resumed the practice of having two sessions a day— Heard the debate there this afternoon, upon the subject of reforming the Judicial department— Evening at home— Read the conclusion of the two Gentlemen of Verona, and began the Merry Wives of Windsor.

16. I went with Mr: Boylston and attended on the Committee of New-Trials, to support his petition against Mr: Gill— The Attorney General and Mr: Lovell attended for Gill— A remonstrance of Gill was read, and some progress made in the discussion— But as Gill ask’d for time to prepare a defence—The Committee adjourned untill the day after to-morrow, 5 o’clock P.M— No business of a very interesting nature before the Senate— Met the Committee upon Jonathan Simpson’s petition and agreed upon a report— At the Senate chamber this afternoon— Met the Committee appointed to consider the expediency of amending the laws respecting usury— Agreed to report a bill, which I am to draw— Drew up the report upon Jonathan Simpson’s petition, and shewed it to two of the members from the House on the Committee, who approved it— The House continued their debate on the reform of the Judiciary— They Committed the bill to a large Committee of a member from each County. Mr: Gardner went with me and pass’d an hour at my Office— Evening with the club at Dr: Warren’s.

17. The New-Bedford Bank Bill came before the Senate this morning; having pass’d the House of Representatives— To have a second reading next Monday.— I drew up a Bill repealing the usury Laws, and providing a different system against that practice. I presume however it will not pass— Reported upon Jonathan Simpson’s petition. Dined and spent the Evening at Mr: Gardner Greene’s.— The Governor and about twenty Gentlemen there. Play’d Whist with Dr: Lloyd Mr: Babcock, and Mr: Allen the Sheriff— Home about 10.— A Snow-storm.

18. Drew a bill to require semi-annual statements from the Banks to be return’d— In the afternoon I heard the debates in the House of Representatives— After they rose, I attended the Committee on Mr: Boylston’s petition— Mr: Sullivan and Mr: Lovell, appeared on the part of Mr: Gill— The Question was argued by Mr: Sullivan and Mr: Lowell, who attended, untill after 9. in the evening.— The Committee then remained to come to a decision— Mr: Boylston took me in his sleigh to Mr: Emerson’s where the Society were assembled, and Mr: Quincy performed several chemical experiments to illustrate the doctrine of affinities.

19. The Boston Bank Bill, was read the first time, and committed untill the second reading— Same of the bill for incorporating the first parish in the town of Charlestown— Attended in the afternoon at my Office— Mr: Quincy was there an hour or two— On returning home this Evening I found Mr: Hellen had arrived— This Evening, about half an hour after supper, Mrs: Adams was taken excessively ill— Sent for Dr: Welsh— Her illness was not of so long continuance as it has been sometimes; but I have scarcely ever known it more severe.

20. Mrs: Adams was better, though very weak, all this day— Heard Dr: Howard in the morning, and Mr: Emerson in the afternoon— Mr: Hellen with us after dinner— Called with him in the Evening at Mr: Smith’s— I could neither read nor write as usual, this day.

21. The Committee of the Senate upon Mr: Boylston’s petition reported that he have leave to withdraw it, which was accepted— I attended the Bankrupt Office on a meeting to make a dividend in the case of Joseph Ripley— At 2. P.M. adjourned till 11. to-morrow morning— In the afternoon, attended upon two Committees; one on an application for a Bank at Saco— And the other on the Boston Bank Bill— Adjourned from the last untill to-morrow afternoon— In the evening I went to the play, where I found Mr: Hellen and the Ladies— Alexander the Great, and the Prize were performed—poorly.

22. The report of the Committee upon Jonathan Simpson’s petition was discussed; the general sense of the Committee appeared to be against the report. The subject further postponed untill Mr: Pickman shall come in— Mr: Storer of Portland, and Mr: Jo. Hall dined with us— This afternoon, when I went up to the Committee-Room, I found the members all going away— They had met and adjourned, without doing any business— I called and spent a couple of hours with Mr: Quincy; and afterwards an hour with Mr: Parsons— I am very desirous that the petitioners for the new Bank in Boston, should consent to refer the subject over to the next General Court— But probably they will not.

23. The Newbury-Port Turnpike was before the Senate— The Boston Bank postponed untill to-morrow, the Committee not being ready to report. They met in the afternoon, and finally agreed upon the principle of a report on the point upon which they were instructed; which General Skinner the chairman desired me to draw up— Evening at the club at Mr: John Welles’s— It was thinly attended.

24. The Newbury-Port Turnpike bill pass’d at a second reading— The Boston Bank Bill was partly discussed, untill the adjournment— Dined with Mr: Babcock— At 5. Returned to the Committee Rooms— Had a petition for another Bank at Newbury-Port; and gave leave to bring in a bill— We agreed also, against General Skinner’s opinion to report the bill for the Incorporation of the first parish in Charlestown, as we received it— Went to the Ball in the Evening, with the ladies. I danc’d and play’d some time at whist— Home, after Midnight.

25. Continued the discussion upon the Boston Bank Bill all the forenoon and left it still unfinished. The Senate agreed for the remainder of the Session to meet in the afternoon— I dined at R. Amory’s with Judge Sedgwick, Judge Strong, Mr: J. C. Williams, and several other Gentlemen; and also several ladies— Return’d to the Senate in the afternoon— No business of consequence transacted— Examined with Mr: Pickman the tax-act— In the evening attended at the meeting of the Society— Heard Judge Davis read— And Mr: Quincy made several experiments.

26. Debated the Boston Bank Bill the whole morning, and untill the adjournment 1/2 past two— Still left the main question undecided— The petitioners had to contend this whole day to restore a section which they spent the whole day yesterday to reject— It is at length incorporated into the bill— In the afternoon I went out with Mr: Shaw to Quincy in the sleigh sent into town.

27. Heard Mr: Bowes Whitney, of Hingham, the whole day. Spent all the leisure time in reading Stuart on political economy— The part which treats of Banks— It confirms my opposition to the Banks now projected. Captn: Beale and my uncle Adams spent the Evening with us.

28. Return’d with Mr Shaw to Boston this forenoon— Attended at the Senate— Unimportant business transacted in the morning.— At 3 in the afternoon the Boston Bank Bill was again taken up, and debated untill the evening.— The question was finally taken by yeas and nays— Yea’s 13. Nays 12. Mr: Taft was absent— Had he been here— The President would have decided the vote— But the decision would have been the same— I spent the Evening at home; reading part of the Merry Wives of Windsor to the Ladies.

Day— Rise seldom before 8. Read or write untill 10. Breakfast— Attend at the Senate untill 1/2 past one. Call at my Office for half an hour— Home to dinner— At the Senate chamber again from three to 6, or 7, and sometimes 9— Remainder of the Evenings, at home, at club, at the Society, at the Balls, or in Company upon private parties— A life, more of business than of profit.
